document.docAuthor: Huber, Bernhard A., Nuñeza, Olga M. & Leh Moi Ung, Charles
document.masterDocTitle: The Philippine hair wax spiders and their relatives: revision of the Pholcus bicornutus species group (Araneae, Pholcidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Philippine hair wax spiders and their relatives: revision of the Pholcus bicornutus species group (Araneae, Pholcidae)

bibRefCitation.author: Walckenaer C. A.
bibRefCitation.refString: Walckenaer C. A. 1805. Tableau des araneides ou caracteres essentiels des tribus, genres, familles et races que renferme le genre Aranea de Linne, avec la designation des especes comprises dans chacune de ces divisions. E. Dentu, Paris.
bibRefCitation.title: Tableau des araneides ou caracteres essentiels des tribus, genres, familles et races que renferme le genre Aranea de Linne, avec la designation des especes comprises dans chacune de ces divisions

subSubSection.paragraph:
Pholcus Walckenaer, 1805 : 80
. Type species by (assumed) monotypy:
Aranea phalangioides Fuesslin, 1775
.

Large, long-legged
Pholcus
(body length ~5–8, male leg 1 length: ~40–60) with cylindrical abdomen, eight eyes, and rather dark coloration; distinguished from similar insular Southeast Asian species groups (
P. gracillimus
group;
P. ancoralis
group; cf. Huber 2011a ) by male ocular area with unique pair of processes, each carrying brush of hairs ( Figs 12–13 , 63–67 , 78 , 92 ) (
P. ancoralis
group also with horns but without brushes of hairs), by male palpal tibia very large relative to femur (in contrast to
P. ancoralis
species group), and by paired anterior marks in dorsal abdominal pattern ( Figs 3 , 36 , 50 , 55 ; unpaired in
P. gracillimus
and
P. ancoralis
groups).
The eight species assigned to this group are here divided into two operational sub-groups:

caption.paragraph:
Figs 1–2. Known distributions of the two subgroups of the
Pholcus bicornutus
species group.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Seven of the eight named species were observed in the field. They occupied a variety of microhabitats, ranging from caves (close to the ground;
P. bicornutus
) and wet rock walls (
P. olangapo
sp. nov. ) to dark sheltered spaces among rocks (
P. mulu
sp. nov. ,
P. baguio
sp. nov. ,
P. pagbilao
), large holes at tree bases (
P. kawit
sp. nov. ), abandoned buildings (
P. pagbilao
), and open space among vegetation exposed to direct sunlight (
P. arayat
). Webs mainly consisted of a domed sheet with a diameter of up to ~ 50 cm (
P. mulu
sp. nov. ), but were much smaller in the rock-dwelling
P. olangapo
sp. nov. (~ 15 cm ). In
P. baguio
sp. nov. , webs were connected to each other and formed large communal structures up to 2 m in length. When disturbed, most species were observed to run toward the periphery of the web, seeking shelter at the substrate rather than staying and whirling in the web.

The
Pholcus bicornutus
group is largely restricted to the Philippines, with only one species in NE Borneo ( Figs 1–2 ).
